"summary": {"eng": "WILMINGTON, Del. -- First son Hunter Biden's criminal trial kicked off Monday in Delaware with jury selection, which revealed that the majority of potential jurors have personally been affected by drug addiction in their own families or social circles.\n\n\"This is Delaware. You can't swing a cat without hearing something [about the case],\" one male potential juror told the court Monday.\n\nPresident Biden's son, Hunter Biden, is facing three felony firearm offenses regarding the 2018 purchase of a .3"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Wilmington, Delaware"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Gun_Control", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Gun Control", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Show_Jumping", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Equestrian/Show Jumping", "wgt": 12}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Trials", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Trials", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 96}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 178}, "sentiment": -0.2235294117647059, "breakingScore": 0.9833193284443148}
{"uri": "2024-06-378683611", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:51:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:51:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:36:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/president-bidens-brother-sons-widow-among-witnesses-expected-at-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial/article_86906149-0f67-5d5f-854e-38abd80a70b5.html", "title": "President Biden's brother, son's widow among witnesses expected at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial", "body": "Opening statements in Hunter Biden's trial based on felony gun charges begin Tuesday morning, now that a jury is in place.\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a \"drug addict\" whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 by saying he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\n\"You will see that he is not guilty,\" attorney Abbe Lowell said.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer. They also played for jurors an audio excerpt of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things\" in which he talked about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict,\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden, who attended Monday's court session, joined him in the courtroom again as opening statements began. Hunter Biden's exes are also expected to testify on embarrassing and personal details about addiction.\n\nLowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nAnd his state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.''\n\nLowell told the jury that prosecutors have to prove that Hunter Biden knowingly violated the law.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at https://apnews.com/hub/hunter-biden.\n\nMore from this section\n\niEmergent's 2024-2026 U.S. Mortgage Origination Forecast is now available in Mortgage MarketSmart\n\nCEOs got hefty pay raises in 2023, widening the gap with the workers they oversee\n\nAmerican Pacific Mortgage Picks Fee Chaser by LenderLogix to Collect Upfront Borrower Fees", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8161295253", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:31:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:31:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:31:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-trial-lawyers-present-opening-statements-101717509991405.html", "title": "Hunter Biden's federal firearms trial: lawyers present opening statements", "body": "Lawyers are making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, on Tuesday morning, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.", "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", {"uri": "2024-06-378477547", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:43:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:43:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:03:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case-opens-after-jury-is-chosen-with-first-lady-again-sitting/article_55c65911-68e5-557e-a63e-d55282068379.html", "title": "Hunter Biden's federal firearms case opens after jury is chosen, with first lady again sitting in", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers will make their opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter after a jury was seated for the trial.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at {"uri": "8161335156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:58:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:58:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:58:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/lawyers-begin-opening-statements-in-hunter-biden-s-federal-firearms-case-1.6912585", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "Lawyers will make their opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against U.S. President Joe Biden's son Hunter after a jury was seated for the trial.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom as openings began.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken centre stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay US$1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offences to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defence table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Conn.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the spectre of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", {"uri": "2024-06-378568774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:03:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:03:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:47:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/hunter-bidens-attorney-says-hell-call-presidents-brother-as-a-witness-in-federal-gun-trial/article_86906149-0f67-5d5f-854e-38abd80a70b5.html", "title": "Hunter Biden's attorney says he'll call president's brother as a witness in federal gun trial", "body": "Opening statements in Hunter Biden's trial based on felony gun charges begin Tuesday morning, now that a jury is in place.\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a clear drug addict whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 when he said he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\n\"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\nHines said \"addiction is depressing\" but that Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom as opening statements began.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623025", "eventUri": "eng-9623025", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-11", "textStart": 5727, "textEnd": 5734}], "sentiment": -0.2549019607843137, "wgt": 227, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-378540999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:38:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:38:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T06:10:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.weareiowa.com/article/news/nation-world/hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case-begins/507-2e71a0d2-ebb2-4cb1-9d8d-45323baf20ba", "title": "Hunter Biden's federal firearms case is opening after the jury is chosen", "body": "Hunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "weareiowa.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local {"uri": "2024-06-378662566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:30:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:30:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:11:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://keyt.com/ap-california-news/2024/06/04/president-bidens-brother-sons-widow-among-witnesses-expected-at-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial/", "title": "President Biden's brother, son's widow among witnesses expected at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial", "body": "By CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE\n\nAssociated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a \"drug addict\" whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 by saying he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\n\"You will see that he is not guilty,\" attorney Abbe Lowell said.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer. They also played for jurors an audio excerpt of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things\" in which he talked about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict,\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden, who attended Monday's court session, joined him in the courtroom again as opening statements began. Hunter Biden's exes are also expected to testify on embarrassing and personal details about addiction.\n\nLowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nAnd his state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.''\n\nLowell told the jury that prosecutors have to prove that Hunter Biden knowingly violated the law.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://keyt.b-cdn.net/2023/08/nc312-combined-commercial-slate-860x484.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": {"uri": "8161413278", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:49:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:49:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:49:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.americanpress.com/2024/06/04/president-bidens-brother-sons-widow-among-witnesses-expected-at-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial/", "title": "President Biden's brother, son's widow among witnesses expected at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial - American Press", "body": "Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, speaks to guests during the White House Easter Egg Roll on the South Lawn of the White House on April 18, 2022, in Washington. (Associated Press Archives)\n\nFederal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a \"drug addict\" whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 when he said he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer. They also played for jurors an audio excerpt of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things,\" where he talks about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden, who attended Monday's court session, joined him in the courtroom again as opening statements began.\n\nDefense attorney Abbe Lowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nAnd his state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.''\n\nHe told the jury that prosecutors have to prove that Hunter Biden knowingly violated the law.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.", "source": {"uri": "americanpress.com", {"uri": "8161468254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:28:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:28:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:26:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/06/04/bidens-brother-sons-widow-among-witnesses-expected-at-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial/", "title": "Biden's brother, son's widow among witnesses expected at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Biden's son Hunter as a \"drug addict\" whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 by saying he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\n\"You will see that he is not guilty,\" attorney Abbe Lowell said.\n\nHunter Biden departs from federal court, Monday in Wilmington, Del. Matt Slocum/Associated Press\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer. They also played for jurors an audio excerpt of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things\" in which he talked about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict,\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden, who attended Monday's court session, joined him in the courtroom again as opening statements began. Hunter Biden's exes are also expected to testify on embarrassing and personal details about addiction.\n\nLowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nAnd his state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.''\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLowell told the jury that prosecutors have to prove that Hunter Biden knowingly violated the law.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nCopy the Story Link\n\nInvalid username/password.\n\nPlease check your email to confirm and complete your registration.\n\nCreate a commenting profile by providing an email address, password and display name. "https://www.pressherald.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/4/2024/06/Hunter_Biden_05372_d9ddd5-1717518202.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623025", "eventUri": "eng-9623025", "location": {"uri": "2024-06-378507305", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:02:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.brproud.com/news/politics/ap-politics/ap-hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case-is-opening-after-the-jury-is-chosen/", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "by: CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE, Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers are making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, on Tuesday morning, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\n\"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\nHines said \"addiction is depressing\" but that Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election.
