{"uri": "8161258942", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:08:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:08:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:07:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.dailypress.com/2024/06/04/lawyers-begin-opening-statements-in-hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case/", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "By Claudia Lauer | Associated Press, Michael Kunzelman | Associated Press, Colleen Long | The Associated Press and Randall Chase | Associated Press\n\nBy CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE (Associated Press)\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers are making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, on Tuesday morning, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at addiction.\n\nLawyers are making opening statements on Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter, in a trial that is expected to feature evidence from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction.\n\nHe has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user, and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the court with this wife, Melissa.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has said he is being unfairly targeted by the justice department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City.\n\nThe two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken centre stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved quickly on Monday in Delaware, the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established.\n\nJoe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, DC.\n\nThe story of how Joe Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s, is well known.\n\nBeau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at the age of 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and could not be impartial.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay 1.4 million dollars (\u00a31 million) in taxes.\n\nThe Delaware trial is not about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who has long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinised.\n\nThe president must do so while he is campaigning under anaemic poll numbers and preparing for a presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement on Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength\".\n\n\"I am the president, but I am also a dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nJoe Biden was traveling to France on Tuesday and will be away for the rest of the week. Several of those who were selected for the jury are professed gun owners and others said that they had loved ones who suffered with drug problems.\n\nThe president's son owned the Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver for 11 days in October 2018 while he was taking crack cocaine. {"uri": "8161293746", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:30:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:30:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:29:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/world/united-states/lawyers-begin-opening-statements-in-hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case/article_cd7f9c04-6108-5af0-8c4f-229b256e48cf.html", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers are making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, on Tuesday morning, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nYou might be interested in Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 Peterborough And Area News Dec 31, 1969 ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the court with this wife, Melissa.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has said he is being unfairly targeted by the justice department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved quickly on Monday in Delaware, the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established.\n\nJoe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, DC.\n\nThe story of how Joe Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s, is well known.\n\nBeau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at the age of 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and could not be impartial.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay 1.4 million dollars (\u00a31 million) in taxes.\n\nThe Delaware trial is not about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who has long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinised.\n\nThe president must do so while he is campaigning under anaemic poll numbers and preparing for a presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement on Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength\".\n\n\"I am the president, but I am also a dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case.\n\n\"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nJoe Biden was traveling to France on Tuesday and will be away for the rest of the week. The first lady will join him later.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer.\n\nHe bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it is unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan Merchan, who raised the spectre of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.", "source": {"uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Belfast Telegraph"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter_Biden", {"uri": "8161269844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:15:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:15:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:14:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/hunter-bidens-criminal-trial-kicks-off-with-focus-on-phone-messages/article_1c10e646-ff1f-56ec-97e0-cb300f3fc585.html", "title": "Hunter Biden's criminal trial kicks off with focus on phone messages", "body": "U.S. first lady Jill Biden returns to the federal court on the opening day of trial of Hunter Biden, son of U.S. President Joe Biden, on criminal gun charges in Wilmington, Delaware, U.S., June 3, 2024. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque\n\nBy Tom Hals and Jack Queen\n\nWILMINGTON, Delaware (Reuters) -Hunter Biden arrived for his criminal trial on gun charges on Tuesday, ahead of opening statements and potentially lurid testimony about drug use lifted from his autobiography and phone messages that prosecutors say incriminates the president's son.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, is accused of failing to disclose his use of illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver and of illegally possessing the weapon for 11 days in October 2018.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty to the three felony charges. Hunter Biden is the first child of a sitting president to be criminally tried.\n\nHunter Biden did not speak to reporters as he entered court on Tuesday. He was accompanied at the trial by First Lady Jill Biden and his wife.\n\nThe proceeding at the federal courthouse in the Bidens' hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, comes just days after Republican Donald Trump, the rival to Democratic President Joe Biden for the Nov. 5 U.S. election, became the first former president found guilty of a crime.\n\nThe trial is expected to center on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance.\n\nU.S. Special Counsel David Weiss is expected to call FBI agent Erika Jensen to testify about Hunter Biden's messages discussing his drug use and Hunter Biden's autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\"\n\n\"I was sleeping on a car smoking crack on 4th Street and Rodney,\" was one of the messages prosecutors disclosed in a court filing. In another, Hunter Biden said he was behind a minor league baseball stadium in Wilmington \"waiting for a dealer named Mookie.\"\n\nProsecutors said they may call as a witness his former wife, Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nTwelve jurors and four alternates were sworn in on Monday, many describing their own experiences with family members and friends battling substance abuse. All 12 jurors must agree Hunter Biden is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict.\n\nNoreika announced a juror had been \"lost\" before the start of Tuesday's proceeding. The judge said the juror begged to be dismissed because she lived an hour away and didn't have a car, job or money for parking.\n\nWeiss, a Trump appointee, has hit Hunter Biden with federal tax charges separately in California.\n\nThe trial comes days after Trump was convicted by a jury in\n\nstate court in New York of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 U.S. election that put him in the White House.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced in New York on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases, two related to his efforts to overturn his loss in 2020 to Biden and one charging that he unlawfully kept classified national security documents after leaving office in January 2021.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the U.S. Justice Department.\n\nNoreika, also a Trump appointee, entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy.\n\nThe judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.\n\n(Reporting by Tom Hals in Wilmington, Delaware; additional reporting by Stephanie Kelly in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware; Editing by Scott Malone, Leslie Adler and Nick Zieminski)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. "https://www.malaymail.com/malaymail/uploads/images/2024/06/04/thumbs/400x400/215382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9623025", "eventUri": "eng-9623025", "location": {"type": "place", {"uri": "2024-06-378178494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:28:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:28:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:27:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/hunter-biden-trial-opening/60988218", "title": "Opening statements begin in Hunter Biden federal firearms trial", "body": "Lawyers will make their opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter after a jury was seated for the trial while the first lady watched from the courtroom and the president sent a message of support.Hunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.The proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.The trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.Jury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator there, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.People just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at 46 from cancer.Some prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally; others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it only took a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.One potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\"It's not a good one,\" she said.Another was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"But much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.The panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.Hunter Biden also faces a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.But Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.The lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.Opening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.The Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.The president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.In a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"The first lady sat in court all day Monday, on her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife Melissa and sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.Aboard Air Force One Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job and replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\"He always puts the American people first, and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings' conclusion.Biden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.The case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.If convicted, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nLawyers will make their opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter after a jury was seated for the trial while the first lady watched from the courtroom and the president sent a message of support.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator there, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally; others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it only took a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, on her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife Melissa and sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job and replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first, and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings' conclusion.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though {"uri": "8160781847", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:16:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/in-hunter-bidens-trial-on-gun-charges-opening-arguments-to-be-held-today-5813868", "title": "In Hunter Biden's Trial On Gun Charges, Opening Arguments To Be Held Today", "body": "Hunter Biden is also charged with illegal possession of the firearm, which he had for just 11 days in October of that year.\n\nHunter Biden has long been the target of hard-right Republicans (File)\n\nWilmington, United States:\n\nOpening arguments are to be held on Tuesday in the trial of Hunter Biden on gun charges, the first-ever prosecution of a child of a sitting US president.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, the only surviving son of President Joe Biden, is charged with lying about his illegal drug use when buying a handgun in 2018, a felony.\n\nA 12-member jury with four alternates was seated on Monday for the federal trial being held in the Biden hometown of Wilmington.\n\nExpected to last one to two weeks, Hunter Biden's trial comes as his father is seeking reelection, and just days after the conviction on business fraud charges of Donald Trump, the president's likely opponent in November.\n\nThe proceedings, along with another trial in which Hunter Biden faces tax evasion charges in California, complicates Democrats' efforts to keep the focus on Trump, the first former president ever to be convicted of a crime.\n\nTrump also faces three far more serious criminal cases, including for his alleged efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 presidential election.\n\nFirst Lady Jill Biden was in court on Monday for jury selection for Hunter Biden's trial.\n\nThe president did not attend but said he and Jill were \"proud\" of Hunter Biden.\n\n\"As the President, I don't and won't comment on pending federal cases, but as a Dad, I have boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength,\" Biden said in a statement.\n\nIn addition to being a political distraction, Hunter Biden's legal troubles have reopened painful emotional wounds for the family from his time as a drug addict.\n\nHis brother Beau died from cancer in 2015, and his sister Naomi died as an infant in a 1972 car crash that also killed their mother, Neilia, Joe Biden's first wife.\n\nAddiction\n\nThe Yale-trained lawyer and lobbyist-turned-artist is charged with falsely stating when buying a .38 caliber revolver in 2018 that he was not using drugs illegally.\n\nHe is also charged with illegal possession of the firearm, which he had for just 11 days in October of that year.\n\nProsecutors are set to introduce often uncomfortable evidence linked to Hunter Biden's years as an addict.\n\nThe president's son, who has written unsparingly about his addiction, will contend that at the moment he bought the revolver he did not consider himself to be an addict. He has stated that he has been sober since 2019.\n\nIf found guilty, Hunter Biden could face 25 years in prison, although as a first-time offender jail time is unlikely.\n\nPresident Biden said on Monday that his son's difficulties would resonate widely.\n\n\"Hunter's resilience in the face of adversity and the strength he has brought to his recovery are inspiring to us. A lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction and know what we mean,\" he said.\n\nHunter Biden has long been the target of hard-right Republicans, and Trump allies have investigated him at length in Congress on allegations of corruption and influence-peddling. No charges have ever been brought.\n\nHunter Biden's business dealings in China and Ukraine have also formed the basis for attempts by Republican lawmakers to initiate impeachment proceedings against Biden. Those efforts too have gone nowhere.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nThe White House said last year that there would be no presidential pardon for Hunter Biden in case of a conviction.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8160856415", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:01:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:01:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:00:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/06/04/nation/hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case-is-opening-after-jury-is-chosen/", "title": "Hunter Biden's federal firearms case is opening after the jury is chosen - The Boston Globe", "body": "Hunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator there, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally; others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it only took a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public. They included a woman whose sister was convicted about 10 years ago of credit card fraud and drug charges in Delaware, a man whose father had been killed in a crime involving a gun, and a woman married to a former law enforcement officer who is also a licensed gun owner.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a separate trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, on her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife Melissa and sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job and replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first, and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings' conclusion.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hunter Biden is the first child of a sitting president to be criminally tried.\n\nThe proceeding at the federal courthouse in the Bidens' hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, comes just days after Republican Donald Trump, the rival to Democratic President Joe Biden for the Nov. 5 U.S. election, became the first former president found guilty of a crime.\n\nThe trial is expected to centre on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance.\n\nU.S. Special Counsel David Weiss is expected to call FBI agent Erika Jensen to testify about Hunter Biden's messages discussing his drug use and Hunter Biden's autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\"\n\n\"I was sleeping on a car smoking crack on 4th Street and Rodney,\" was one of the messages prosecutors disclosed in a court filing. In another, Hunter Biden said he was behind a minor-league baseball stadium in Wilmington \"waiting for a dealer named Mookie.\"\n\nProsecutors said they may call as a witness his former wife, Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nTwelve jurors and four alternates were sworn in on Monday, many describing their own experiences with family members and friends battling substance abuse. All 12 jurors must agree Hunter Biden is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict.\n\nWeiss, a Trump appointee, has hit Hunter Biden with federal tax charges separately in California.\n\nThe trial comes days after Trump was convicted by a jury in state court in New York of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 U.S. election that put him in the White House.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced in New York on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases, two related to his efforts to overturn his loss in 2020 to Biden and one charging that he unlawfully kept classified national security documents after leaving office in January 2021.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the U.S. Justice Department.\n\nNoreika, also a Trump appointee, entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy.\n\nThe judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8160791726", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:22:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:22:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:21:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/us-news/hunter-bidens-firearms-trial-gets-32954562", "title": "Hunter Biden's firearms trial gets underway - what you need to know", "body": "Opening statements are expected to be heard in Hunter Biden's firearms trial\n\nPresident Joe Biden's son Hunter is facing federal gun charges with lawyers set to make their opening statements in his trial today.\n\nThe trial comes after a jury was selected and with the first lady observing from the courtroom while the president sent a message of support. Hunter Biden faces three felony charges related to a 2018 firearm purchase during a period when he admits in his memoir to struggling with a crack addiction.\n\nHe stands accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, falsely claiming on the application that he wasn't a drug user, and illegally possessing the gun for 11 days. The trial follows the breakdown of a deal with prosecutors that would have sidestepped the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election.\n\nRead more: Biden claims 'convicted felon' Trump is running for office to 'preserve his freedoms'\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and argues that he's being unjustly targeted by the Justice Department following Republican outcry over the now-defunct plea deal as preferential treatment for the Democratic president's son. Hunter Biden has long been a target of attack by Republicans attempting to hit the President by proxy.\n\nThis trial is taking place just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was found guilty of 34 felonies in New York City. While the two criminal cases are unrelated, their timing highlights how the courts have become a focal point during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection for Hunter Biden's case was swiftly completed on Monday in the president's home state, where the Biden family has deep roots. President Joe Biden served as a senator there for 36 years, commuting daily to and from Washington, DC.\n\nThe tragic story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that claimed the lives of his wife and baby daughter in the early 1970s is well-known. Beau Biden, who passed away at 46 from cancer, had previously held the position of state attorney general.\n\nSome potential jurors were dismissed due to personal connections with the Biden family; others were excused because their political views about the Bidens could compromise their impartiality. Despite these challenges, it took just one day to assemble the jury of six men and six women, along with four female alternates, who will preside over the case.\n\nOne prospective juror was dismissed after admitting she had formed an unfavourable opinion of Hunter Biden based on media coverage. \"It's not a good one,\" she confessed.\n\nAnother potential juror was excused after acknowledging his awareness of the case and expressing the view that \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nHowever, much of the questioning centred around issues of drug use, addiction and gun ownership. Lawyers aimed to gauge potential jurors' understanding of the case and dismiss those with strong opinions on drug use or firearm regulation - some of whom are constituents of Biden.\n\nThe jury of 12 was selected from approximately 65 individuals, their identities kept confidential. Among them were a woman whose sister had been convicted of credit card fraud and drug offences in Delaware around a decade ago, a man whose father was a victim of a gun-related crime, and a woman married to an ex-law enforcement officer who is also a licensed firearm owner.\n\nIn addition, Hunter Biden is set to face a separate trial in California this September over allegations of failing to pay $1.4 million (\u00a31.09m) in taxes. Both cases were initially intended to be settled through a deal with prosecutors last July, following a lengthy investigation into his business activities.\n\nHowever, Judge Maryellen Noreika, a Trump nominee, raised questions about some peculiar aspects of the deal. This included a proposed guilty plea for misdemeanour offences to settle the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which would result in the dismissal of the case provided he stayed out of trouble for two years.\n\nThe lawyers failed to resolve her queries, leading to the collapse of the deal. Subsequently, Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed the lead investigator, former US attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August. A month later, Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements kicked off as Garland took the hot seat before the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family. The committee's chairman, a key player in the faltering impeachment inquiry linked to Hunter Biden's business ventures, led the charge.\n\nThe trial in Delaware isn't focused on Hunter Biden's international business dealings, but it's expected to unearth some dark, embarrassing, and distressing memories. The president's supporters are fretting about the emotional toll this trial could have on elder Biden, who has always been deeply concerned about his only surviving son and his battle with addiction.\n\nNow, he must endure the public airing of his son's past missteps while juggling a presidential campaign, lackluster poll figures, and gearing up for a debate with Trump. In a heartfelt statement on Monday, the president expressed his \"boundless love\" for his son, along with \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he declared, stating further that he would refrain from commenting on the ongoing case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady spent her 73rd birthday in court, observing the proceedings silently from the front row behind the defence table alongside Hunter Biden's wife Melissa and sister Ashley. President Biden was mostly at their Wilmington home during the day but left after the court session for a campaign event in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nOn Monday night aboard Air Force One, when White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was questioned about the trial's impact on the president's duties, she firmly stated, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first, and is capable of doing his job,\" Jean-Pierre emphasised, though she did not confirm whether Biden received updates during the day or if he had spoken to his son following the trial. President Biden set off for France on Tuesday evening and will be away for the remainder of the week, with plans for the first lady to join him later.\n\nThe charges against Hunter Biden relate to a time when he has openly admitted to struggling with crack addiction, a problem that escalated after his brother's death from cancer in 2015. During this period, he purchased a firearm and kept it for 11 days in October 2018, falsely claiming on the acquisition form that he was not using drugs.\n\nHunter Biden could face up to 25 years in prison if convicted, although typically, first-time offenders receive much lighter sentences, and it remains uncertain if the judge will impose a prison term.", "source": {"uri": "mirror.co.uk", {"uri": "2024-06-378371000", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "12:11:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T12:11:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T12:06:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2024/06/04/hunter-biden-trial-live-updates/73959164007/", "title": "Hunter Biden trial live updates: The president's son faces case on felony gun charges", "body": "Hunter Biden arrived to court in Delaware with First Lady Jill Biden also attending the first ay of the trial.\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. - Hunter Biden's long struggle with addiction could take center stage today as opening arguments are slated to begin in the controversial trial related to his gun charges.\n\nHunter Biden has pleaded not guilty to all charges, including lying about his drug use when he bought a gun six years ago. The trial could last two weeks.\n\nThe trial has become the focus of the political world on the heels of former President Donald Trump's felony conviction Thursday. Hunter Biden has not played a big role in his father's political life and isn't on the ballot in November.\n\nThe jury was selected Monday with U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika presiding. The 12-member jury has six men and six women, with four women alternates.\n\nFollow along with the USA TODAY Network's live coverage for live updates.\n\nWho is Abbe Lowell?\n\nHunter Biden's main lawyer, Abbe Lowell, has a long history of working with Democrats and Republicans.\n\nLowell represented Ivanka Trump while she was a White House aide, chiming in as an ethics adviser. He also defended Jared Kushner when House members questioned his use of WhatsApp to communicate with foreign leaders.\n\nNow, he is defending Hunter Biden who faces three felony charges related to purchasing a gun in 2018. Biden officially added Lowell to his legal team after a plea deal fell through in July that would have covered tax charges and the gun charges. It was seen at the time as a way to take a more aggressive response to the investigation into him, which have been going on for more than five years.\n\nHe was the chief minority counsel during the impeachment proceedings against President Bill Clinton.\n\nJustice Department special counsel David Weiss, who is overseeing the prosecution of Hunter Biden, was appointed the U.S. attorney in Delaware by former President Donald Trump in 2017.\n\nWeiss investigated Biden for years before reaching a plea agreement for the president's son to admit two tax misdemeanors and enter a pretrial program to potentially erase a drug charge. But U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika refused to rubber stamp because of disputes about whether it would protect Biden from future charges.\n\nAttorney General Merrick Garland appointed Weiss as special counsel in August to continue his investigation. Weiss secured indictments on gun charges in Delaware, in the trial that started Monday, and on tax charges in California, with that trial set to begin Sept. 5.\n\nWeiss has been criticized by Republicans as going too soft on Biden by reaching a \"sweetheart deal\" in the plea agreement. Democrats have criticized him for being too hard on Biden by pursuing charges that are rarely enforced.\n\nGarland has defended Weiss as an independent prosecutor following the facts and the law.\n\n--Kinsey Crowley and Bart Jansen\n\nHunter Biden had family's support during jury selection\n\nHunter Biden, the president's son, enjoyed the support of relatives as the jury selected Monday in his trial on federal gun charges.\n\nThe first lady, Jill Biden, sat in the front row on her birthday, paying rapt attention and taking notes. She had helped raise Hunter Biden after his mother was killed in a car crash when he was young. Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa Cohen Biden, and half-sister Ashley Biden also attended.\n\nPresident Joe Biden, who remained in Wilmington during the jury selection, issued a statement supporting his son despite the political toll the charges have taken on his reelection bid.\n\n\"Our family has been through a lot together, and Jill and I are going to continue to be there for Hunter and our family with our love and support,\" Joe Biden said.\n\nThe president's son faces three firearms felonies in the case that kicked off on Monday.\n\nIn October 2018, Hunter Biden walked into a gun shop north of Wilmington, Delaware and purchased a revolver. People who purchase firearms are required to fill out a standardized form that asks whether they are an unlawful user or are addicted to controlled substances, narcotics and other listed substances. Biden is accused of answering \"no\" to that question on the form.\n\nBut Biden has been open about his longtime struggles with crack cocaine addiction. He's written about it in his book and discussed it during a court hearing last year, stating he's been sober since 2019.\n\nWhile every witness in the case isn't set in stone, there have been reports about who's expected to testify at the Delaware trial.\n\nAt least two employees from the gun store at the center of the case are expected to testify at the trial. Millard Greer, a former state police officer who authored the final investigative report on the incident included in court files, is expected to testify.\n\nHallie Biden, who was married to President Joe Biden's other son, the late Beau Biden, is also expected to provide testimony. Hallie Biden and Hunter Biden were in a relationship in 2018, and she told law enforcement officials she found a gun in Hunter Biden's vehicle and threw it away outside of a Delaware store.", {"uri": "8161394022", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:36:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:36:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:36:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/article/2024/jun/04/hunter-biden-gun-trial", "title": "Hunter Biden gun trial attorney says he will call president's brother as witness", "body": "Federal gun trial gets under way as prosecutors paint Joe Biden's son as drug addict who knew what he was doing in lying on form\n\nFederal prosecutors on Tuesday painted Joe Biden's son Hunter as a clear drug addict whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 when he said he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\nHines said \"addiction is depressing\" but that Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the justice department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe first lady, Jill Biden, and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom as opening statements began.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4m in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a years-long investigation into his business dealings.\n\nOpening statements come as the US attorney general, Merrick Garland, faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, the White House press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre, was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied: \"Absolutely not.\"\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on 11 July by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", {"uri": "2024-06-378249546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "10:28:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T10:28:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T10:04:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.aol.com/testimony-begin-hunter-bidens-criminal-100428241.html", "title": "Testimony to begin in Hunter Biden's criminal trial, with focus on phone messages", "body": "Testimony to begin in Hunter Biden's criminal trial, with focus on phone messages\n\nTom Hals\n\nJune 4, 2024 at 12:04 PM\n\nBy Tom Hals\n\nWILMINGTON, Delaware (Reuters) - Hunter Biden's criminal trial on gun charges will begin in earnest on Tuesday with opening statements and potentially lurid testimony about drug use from his autobiography and phone messages that prosecutors say incriminates the president's son.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, is accused of failing to disclose his use of illegal drugs when he bought a Colt Cobra .38-caliber revolver and of illegally possessing the weapon for 11 days in October 2018.\n\nHe has pleaded not guilty to the three felony charges. Hunter Biden is the first child of a sitting president to be criminally tried.\n\nThe proceeding at the federal courthouse in the Bidens' hometown of Wilmington, Delaware, comes just days after Republican Donald Trump, the rival to Democratic President Joe Biden for the Nov. 5 U.S. election, became the first former president found guilty of a crime.\n\nThe trial is expected to center on Hunter Biden's years-long crack cocaine use and addiction, which he has discussed publicly and which was a prominent part of his 2021 autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\" He told U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika at a hearing last year that he has been sober since the middle of 2019.\n\nProsecutors will seek to prove that Hunter Biden knew he was lying when he ticked the box \"no\" next to a question on a federal gun purchase form asking if he was an unlawful user of a controlled substance.\n\nU.S. Special Counsel David Weiss is expected to call FBI agent Erika Jensen to testify about Hunter Biden's messages discussing his drug use and Hunter Biden's autobiography, \"Beautiful Things.\"\n\n\"I was sleeping on a car smoking crack on 4th Street and Rodney,\" was one of the messages prosecutors disclosed in a court filing. In another, Hunter Biden said he was behind a minor league baseball stadium in Wilmington \"waiting for a dealer named Mookie.\"\n\nProsecutors said they may call as a witness his former wife, Kathleen Buhle, who accused Hunter Biden in their 2017 divorce proceedings of squandering money on drugs, alcohol and prostitutes.\n\nTwelve jurors and four alternates were sworn in on Monday, many describing their own experiences with family members and friends battling substance abuse. All 12 jurors must agree Hunter Biden is guilty beyond a reasonable doubt to convict.\n\nWeiss, a Trump appointee, has hit Hunter Biden with federal tax charges separately in California.\n\nThe trial comes days after Trump was convicted by a jury in state court in New York of 34 felony counts of falsifying documents to cover up hush money paid to a porn star to avoid a sex scandal shortly before the 2016 U.S. election that put him in the White House.\n\nHunter Biden's trial gives Republicans a chance to shift attention away from Trump's legal troubles. Trump is due to be sentenced in New York on July 11. He has pleaded not guilty in three other pending criminal cases, two related to his efforts to overturn his loss in 2020 to Biden and one charging that he unlawfully kept classified national security documents after leaving office in January 2021.\n\nIf convicted on all charges in the Delaware case, Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison, though defendants generally receive shorter sentences, according to the U.S. Justice Department.\n\nNoreika, also a Trump appointee, entered multiple orders over the weekend that were requested by prosecutors and that appeared to undercut Biden's legal strategy.\n\nThe judge said Biden's legal team could not introduce expert testimony that people suffering from substance abuse disorder might not consider themselves an addict.\n\n(Reporting by Tom Hals in Wilmington, Delaware; additional reporting by Stephanie Kelly in Rehoboth Beach, Delaware; Editing by Leslie Adler)", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"},
