{"uri": "8161344245", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:05:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:05:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:03:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/hunter-bidens-attorney-says-hell-call-presidents-brother-as-a-witness-in-federal-gun-trial/article_d2af6bdc-5cb2-5f0f-9b20-7ed30913f4fd.html", "title": "Hunter Biden's attorney says he'll call president's brother as a witness in federal gun trial", "body": "Hunter Biden, left, arrives with his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden at federal court, Tuesday, June 4, 2024, in Wilmington, Del.\n\nBy CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE - Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a clear drug addict whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 when he said he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nPeople are also reading... 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Car rolls over on Highway 29 in Napa Napa's Oxbow RiverStage concert series goes on hiatus as promoters seek new site Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda Letter: Concerned for the future of the wine industry NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa doctor launches concierge medical practice and fights obesity epidemic Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\n\"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\nHines said \"addiction is depressing\" but that Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom as opening statements began.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at https://apnews.com/hub/hunter-biden.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161101243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "12:31:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T12:31:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T12:30:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.fox13now.com/Politics/political-scandals/opening-statements-set-to-begin-in-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial", "title": "Opening statements set to begin in Hunter Biden's federal gun trial", "body": "Hunter Biden is the first child of a sitting president to stand trial on criminal charges. (Scripps News)\n\nOpening statements are set to begin Tuesday morning in the federal firearms case against Hunter Biden.\n\nBiden is the first child of a sitting president to stand trial on criminal charges. This trial comes just days after former President Donald Trump's hush money trial ended in a conviction, making him the first president convicted of a crime.\n\nBiden faces up to 25 years in prison for allegedly lying about his drug addiction when he bought a handgun back in 2018.\n\nThe accusations come from Biden's own book, \"Beautiful Things: A Memoir,\" in which the president's son recounted his drug addiction while also mentioning his purchase of a firearm six years ago. He is being accused of lying on the gun form when he checked a box saying he wasn't addicted to drugs. Prosecutors are expected to use Biden's own words against him.\n\nThe trial, taking place in Wilmington, Delaware, began Monday with jury selection. First lady Jill Biden joined her stepson in support at the courthouse.\n\nA jury of six men and six women was seated on Monday.\n\nMore than 65 potential jurors were questioned and at least 29 were dismissed. The candidates, whose names were not made public, answered questions from Judge Maryellen Noreika about their knowledge of the case so far, their views on gun ownership and their ability to remain impartial.\n\nPolitical Scandals\n\nJury seated in Hunter Biden's gun trial Ava-joye Burnett 7:04 AM, Jun 03, 2024\n\nBiden repeatedly tried to avoid standing trial in this case.\n\nLast year, Biden and prosecutors had been on the brink of finalizing a plea deal, but it unexpectedly fell apart at the last minute when Noreika scrutinized the agreement.\n\nBiden has said the indictment against him is based on politics.\n\n\"I have made mistakes in my life, and wasted opportunities and privileges I was afforded. For that, I am responsible. For that, I am accountable. And for that, I am making amends,\" Biden had said in a news conference.\n\nThe president's son previously pleaded not guilty to the charges.\n\nOn Monday, President Joe Biden -- who had yet to comment publicly on the trial -- issued a statement in support of his son.\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad. Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today. Hunter's resilience in the face of adversity and the strength he has brought to his recovery are inspiring to us. A lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction and know what we mean,\" said President Biden.\n\n\"As the President, I don't and won't comment on pending federal cases, but as a Dad, I have boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength. Our family has been through a lot together, and Jill and I are going to continue to be there for Hunter and our family with our love and support,\" he continued.\n\nThe trial could last as long as two weeks.", "source": {"uri": "fox13now.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSTU"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hunter_Biden", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "8161288048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:27:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:27:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:26:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/world/united-states/lawyers-begin-opening-statements-in-hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case/article_4f29c3a0-3aeb-5557-9593-1560d406bb1c.html", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "WILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers began making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nProsecutors told the jury that Hunter Biden was clearly an addict when he bought the gun, and that he told his brother's widow he was waiting for a drug dealer just days after he lied on the form.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom as openings began.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women, plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nMuch of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case. They dismissed those with strong thoughts on drug use or who might want to tighten regulations on firearms.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\n___\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at {"uri": "2024-06-378202787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "09:49:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T09:49:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T09:13:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.aol.com/jill-biden-spends-unusual-birthday-091324679.html", "title": "Jill Biden spends an unusual birthday in court, watching as Hunter Biden's felony trial begins", "body": "Jill Biden spends an unusual birthday in court, watching as Hunter Biden's felony trial begins\n\nSwapna Venugopal Ramaswamy, USA TODAY\n\nJune 4, 2024 at 11:13 AM\n\nWILMINGTON - Jill Biden spent her birthday in a federal courtroom.\n\nThe first lady took a front-row seat as Hunter Biden, the son of President Joe Biden, sat in U.S. District Court in Delaware on Monday for the first day of his trial on felony gun charges. Flanked by her daughter Ashley and her daughter-in-law Melissa Cohen Biden, they made a trifecta of support as the highly watched case got underway.\n\nAshley Biden is Hunter's half-sister and Cohen Biden is Hunter's wife. The first lady raised Hunter Biden after the death of the president's first wife in a 1972 car accident. As courtrooms scenes go, the show of presidential family figures in full view of the jury made for an unusual sight.\n\nWearing a purple monochromatic pantsuit, Valentino stilettos and a perfectly coiffed mane, Jill Biden was a powerful presence in the courtroom. As the jury selection process got underway, she could be seen paying rapt attention and taking notes as well as frequently whispering to the women by her side. During breaks, she would wait for Hunter Biden to leave the defense table and give him a hug before exiting the room.\n\nIt was apparent that the first lady's stature was that of any ordinary relative of a defendant. She got up, with everyone else in the courtroom, to \"All rise\" when U.S. District Court Judge Maryellen Noreika entered.\n\nBy the afternoon, a diverse jury had been selected. The first lady sat across from everyday Delaware citizens who would soon decide her son's fate.\n\nThe scene was reminiscent of former President Donald Trump's hush money trial and conviction in a New York City courtroom last week. It's a rare moment in history to see so many presidential figures and wannabes packed into courtrooms where their fates and families' fortunes are being decided.\n\nHunter Biden faces three felonies over whether he lied on a federal gun form in 2018 that asked if he was addicted to drugs.\n\nAmong Joe Biden's family who were conspicuously absent Monday were his ex-wife Kathleen Buhle and Hallie Biden, his former sister-in-law whom he dated in the aftermath of his brother's death. They are both expected to be called on as witnesses by the prosecution.\n\nFor many, Joe Biden's focus on family is a big part of his image. In 2014, Biden, then vice-president, famously sent a message to his staff, that said, in part: \"If I find out that you are working with me while missing important family responsibilities, it will disappoint me greatly. This has been an unwritten rule since my days in the Senate.\"\n\nHaving lost his first wife and daughter at age 29 has shaped the president and the way he views his commitment to family. In 2015, tragedy struck again when he lost his older son, Beau Biden at age 46 to a brain tumor.\n\nThe president spent Sunday night with the whole family in their Delaware home and was off on a campaign trip to Connecticut Monday afternoon.\n\nStill, for some, the legal spectacles have sown more doubts.\n\nAmong potential jurors at the Biden trial, there were some who said they believed that government and law enforcement \"investigates and prosecutes individuals because of politics.\"\n\nSome pointed to the Trump trial as an example. Still others said they felt Biden was being unfairly targeted because of his father.\n\nAmong supporters at the courtroom was Ricky Mouse, president of the Delaware chapter of the NAACP and a longtime Biden friend.\n\n\"I have known Hunter from when he was about three years old,\" he said. \"He's getting crucified because of his name. And that's wrong. This man have no business in this court whatsoever. And that's the way I see it.\"\n\nBoth Hunter and Jill Biden hugged Mouse when they saw him.\n\n\"Hunter said I took a lot of tension off of him,\" he said afterward.\n\nSwapna Venugopal Ramaswamy is a White House correspondent for USA TODAY. You can follow her on X, formerly Twitter, @SwapnaVenugopal\n\nThis article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Jill Biden emerges as a fierce protector of Hunter Biden", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", {"uri": "8161564817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:42:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:42:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:40:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://weisradio.com/2024/06/04/hunter-biden-gun-trial-updates-defense-says-hunter-biden-wasnt-addict-at-time-of-purchase/", "title": "Hunter Biden gun trial updates: Defense says Hunter Biden wasn't addict at time of purchase - WEIS | Local & Area News, Sports, & Weather", "body": "(WILMINGTON, Del.) -- President Joe Biden's son Hunter Biden is on trial in Delaware on three felony charges related to his efforts to obtain a firearm in 2018 while allegedly addicted to drugs.\n\nThe son of a sitting president has never before faced a criminal trial.\n\nThe frequency of updates may be limited due to federal court restrictions:\n\nJun 04, 12:04 PM\n\nDefense says Hunter Biden wasn't addict at time of purchase\n\nHunter Biden's attorney sought to cast doubt on the government's narrative during his opening statement, claiming that Hunter Biden was not actively using drugs at the time of his gun purchase and therefore did not \"knowingly\" lie on the federal form barring drug users from procuring a firearm.\n\n\"He did not knowingly violate these laws,\" attorney Abbe Lowell said, since there was \"nothing on the form about the definition of a user.\"\n\nLowell told the jury that Hunter Biden was using alcohol at the time of the gun purchase, but that his drug use \"did not start until later.\"\n\nThe attorney said that while Hunter Biden was in Delaware, where he purchased the gun, his behavior was \"totally inconsistent\" with how he presented it when he was on drugs.\n\n\"He spoke with his father, his uncle, his daughters,\" Lowell said, suggesting they would have noticed if he was \"smoking crack every 15 minutes,\" as he described in his 2021 memoir, \"Beautiful Things.\"\n\n\"There is no such thing as a high-functioning crack addict,\" Lowell said.\n\nLowell told the jury that Hunter Biden had entered a 12-day rehab program in California before returning to Delaware in the fall of 2018, just a week before the gun purchase, shepherded by his \"Uncle Jimmy Biden,\" who Lowell suggested will testify at trial.\n\nLowell also pushed back on one of the government's key pieces of evidence -- a text Hunter sent to his then-romantic partner Halle Biden days after purchasing the gun, in which he claimed to be \"on a car\" smoking crack. Prosecutors said this was evidence that he was using drugs at the time, but Lowell said that, \"in reality, he did not want to see Hallie.\"\n\nAs part of the defense, Lowell also appeared to shift some blame to the owners and employees at the gun store where Hunter Biden purchased the gun, saying they \"wanted to make a sale.\"\n\nLowell claimed that Hunter Biden first purchased a BB gun and a knife at the store, and only purchased the gun after they approached him.\n\n\"Hunter wouldn't have known what a speedloader was,\" said Lowell, who also claimed the salesman never \"took Hunter through\" the form to ensure he understood it.\n\n\"How quickly does a person check through those boxes?\" Lowell asked jurors.\n\nLowell also pushed back on allegations involving the gun pouch that was found with the firearm after Hallie Biden threw the gun it in a dumpster. Prosecutors allege that the pouch had cocaine residue on it, but Lowell said it was never checked for fingerprints and called into question its chain of custody.\n\n\"Hunter has never asked anyone to excuse his mistakes,\" Lowell said, before asking jurors to find him not guilty.\n\nAs Lowell delivered his opening statement, first lady Jill Biden, Hunter Biden's wife Melissa Cohen Biden, and his stepsister Ashley Biden sat largely stoic in the gallery. Hunter Biden kept his eyes on Lowell and his hands clasped. Jurors paid close attention, with several taking notes.\n\nJun 04, 10:51 AM\n\nHunter Biden 'chose to lie,' prosecutor tells jury\n\nGovernment prosecutors told jurors in the trial's opening statements that they should make \"no distinction for Hunter Biden or anybody else\" as they weigh the gun case against the president's son.\n\nHunter Biden \"chose to lie,\" prosecutor Derek Hines said, laying out the case that the defendant purchased a gun while knowing he was an addict and drug user.\n\nHines said Hunter Biden bought the firearm from a gun seller who will testify as a witness that the younger Biden filled out form 4473 -- consenting to a federal background check -- and certified that he understood the form. The prosecution said it will show Hunter Biden \"bought a gun and lied during a background check.\"\n\nThe man who sold Hunter Biden the gun will testify that he watched the defendant fill out the form.\n\nThe gun was then \"taken by someone concerned he had a gun. That person was Halle Biden,\" Hines said, referring to Hunter Biden's romantic partner at the time.\n\nHalle Biden disposed of the gun in a dumpster, where it was retrieved by a man who will also be a witness called by the government.\n\n\"The police were called\" when Halle Biden went to retrieve the gun, Hines said.\n\nHines, in his opening, said evidence will show that \"Hunter Biden knew he was a drug user and a drug addict\" when he filled out the form.\n\nHines cited Hunter Biden's memoir, \"Beautiful Things,\" in which he wrote he had a \"superpower of buying crack anywhere, anytime.\"\n\nIn text messages presented by the prosecution, Hunter Biden acknowledged, \"I am an addict.\"\n\nJun 04, 10:09 AM\n\n'No one is above the law,' prosecutor says in opening\n\nOpening statements got underway in Hunter Biden's gun trial after nearly an hour-long delay.\n\nThe jury was seated just before 10 a.m.\n\n\"No one is above the law,\" prosecutor Derek Hines said in his opening statement, addressing the jury from the lectern.\n\n\"It doesn't matter who you are or what your name is,\" Hines told them.\n\nJun 04, 9:29 AM\n\nJudge says they 'lost' a juror overnight\n\nJudge Maryellen Noreika took the bench this morning and announced they had \"lost\" one juror overnight after she \"begged\" to be released due to travel difficulties.\n\n\"We lost a juror overnight,\" Judge Noreika said, noting the juror explained she lives far away and does not have a car. Noreika did not specifically address how they would be moving forward, but there are four alternates who were seated yesterday as part of the jury.\n\nOpening statements had still not gotten underway as of 9 a.m., as the court was still awaiting the arrival of four of the jurors.\n\nJudge Noreika used the time to address a number of motions, including rejecting a motion from Hunter Biden's attorney Abbe Lowell seeking to exclude from evidence a number of photos of Hunter Biden.\n\nThe government said they needed a photo to prove Biden was in Malibu at a particular time, and the judge agreed to admit it.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden was back in her same front-row seat as yesterday, seated between Hunter Biden's wife Melissa and Jill Biden's daughter Ashley Biden.\n\nJun 04, 8:46 AM\n\nHunter Biden arrives at courthouse\n\nHunter Biden has arrived at the courthouse for Day 2 of his federal gun trial.\n\nHunter Biden returns to court this morning for the start of arguments in his federal gun trial.\n\nAttorneys with special counsel David Weiss' office and lawyers for Hunter Biden are both scheduled to deliver opening statements in the case.\n\nJudge Maryellen Noreika yesterday swore in a jury of six men and six women, completing the jury selection process in a single day to put the trial two days ahead of schedule.\n\nJun 03, 6:06 PM\n\nFriends, family look on during Day 1 in court\n\nHunter Biden spent the first day of his gun trial taking notes, reading documents placed in front of him by his attorneys, and often turning to catch a glimpse of the friends and family who came to court to support him.\n\nAt one point, he nodded along as a prospective juror spoke about her friend's overdose after addiction.\n\nJill Biden was seated behind Hunter Biden all day, and she watched attentively as some jurors told the court that they had such a skewed view of her family that they could not be impartial. The first lady did not appear to react in those moments, but at times her daughter Ashley Biden placed her hand on the first lady's back in support.\n\nHunter Biden's family members also appeared to be actively involved with his defense strategy -- at one point standing up and huddling with Hunter Biden's attorneys Abbe Lowell and David Kolansky after a sidebar.\n\nWhen court was dismissed, Jill Biden gave Hunter Biden a hug and a kiss before he walked out hand-in-hand with his wife.\n\nJun 03, 5:49 PM\n\nAfter opening statements, FBI agent will be first witness\n\nHunter Biden and his stepmother, first lady Jill Biden, departed court at the conclusion of the day's jury selection proceedings.\n\nWith opening statements set for Tuesday, prosecutors said their first witness would be FBI Special Agent Erika Jensen, who will introduce into evidence several of Hunter Biden's text messages, as well as excerpts from his 2021 memoir, Beautiful Things, and other evidence.\n\nThe parties had carved out three days to select a jury, which means the proceedings are currently running ahead of schedule.\n\nJudge Maryellen Noreika told jurors they would likely need to be available for the trial through June 14, with the possibility of deliberations stretching into the week of June 17.\n\nJun 03, 5:32 PM\n\nJury of six men, six women will hear openings Tuesday\n\nA jury of six men and six women is scheduled to hear opening statements Tuesday in Hunter Biden's federal gun trial.\n\nAn additional four women were chosen as the alternate jurors.\n\nThe jurors include a Secret Service retiree, a man whose father was killed by a gun, and a number of jurors whose family and friends have suffered from addiction -- a central theme in the case against Hunter Biden.\n\nJuror No. 1 is a woman who recently heard about Hunter Biden's case on the evening news. Said said her sister is also an addict, but is \"currently clean.\"\n\nJuror No. 2 is a woman who worked for the Secret Service for nearly 25 years and is now retired. Her husband was a uniformed officer in Washington, D.C.\n\nJuror No. 3 is woman who gets her news from YouTube. When asked what she has heard about the case, she said that it involves guns and drugs.\n\nJuror No. 4 is a woman who said she feels people who smoke weed \"should not be allowed\" to own a gun, but said she could set that aside.\n\nJuror No. 5 is a currently unemployed man who previously received a DUI for which he pleaded guilty.\n\nJuror No. 6 is a man who said he previously knew about the case. He currently owns three pistols and said, \"I believe the Second Amendment is very important.\"\n\nJuror No. 7 is a man whose father owned a firearm. He said he knows \"some\" gun laws.\n\nJuror No. 8 is a man whose father was killed by a gun in 2004. He has a brother who was arrested for drug possession and was sentenced to prison.\n\nJuror No. 9 is a woman whose home was burglarized years ago. She purchased a gun and has had it for over 20 years.\n\nJuror No. 10 is a man whose brother and brother-in-law both suffered from alcoholism and are now both deceased. His niece and nephew both own guns.\n\nJuror No. 11 is a woman whose family hunts and has hunting rifles. She said her \"childhood best friend\" passed away from a drug overdose.\n\nJuror No. 12 is a man whose older brother is an addict who has been to rehab multiple times for PCP and heroin. He said the brother had a gun but he was not sure when.\n\nJun 03, 4:24 PM\n\nJury is seated\n\nThe jury of 12 jurors and four alternates has been seated in Hunter Biden's federal gun trial.\n\nThe panel was picked from 250 prospective jurors who arrived at the courthouse this morning for the voir dire process.\n\nJun 03, 1:50 PM\n\nMany prospective jurors know of Hunter Biden's travails\n\nJudge Maryellen Noreika has so far quizzed more than 50 Delaware residents about their fitness to serve as jurors in the first trial of a sitting president's son. And being Delaware -- a small state that Joe Biden represented in the Senate for more than three decades -- nearly all of them had some level of familiarity with Hunter Biden's legal travails.\n\n\"I live in Delaware,\" one prospective juror said. \"You can't swing a cat without hearing something.\"\n\n\"Delaware is a small place,\" another said. \"So you hear stuff.\"\n\nSeveral jurors said they had heard or read about this trial specifically. Most had only a cursory understanding of the case, but others expressed a detailed accounting of the charges. A few jurors mentioned the ill-fated plea deal that Hunter Biden initially struck with prosecutors last summer.\n\n\"At one time there was a deal, and then there wasn't,\" one man said.\n\nOne woman had even read Hunter Biden's memoir, \"Beautiful Things,\" which prosecutors plan to use to help prove their case. She was excused by the judge.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has emerged repeatedly in questioning, with prospective jurors expressing both positive and negative feelings on his presidency. One woman said she believed that Hunter Biden was facing charges largely because his father is the president.\n\n\"I think it was a very strong factor,\" she said.\n\nSeveral others have been dismissed for harboring negative views toward the Bidens. Asked for his opinion about the president, one man said, \"Not a good one.\" Another man said, \"Negative toward the defendant.\" Both were excused.\n\nThe jury questionnaire also includes several questions about drug and alcohol addiction -- an affliction that many prospective jurors said has personally affected them.\n\nOne woman held back tears as she described how her best friend had died of a heroine overdose. Another man said his daughter is a recovering addict.\n\n\"Everybody needs a second chance,\" he said.\n\nJudge Noreika has been pressing ahead, intent on getting a jury seated as soon as possible -- perhaps even by the end of the day.\n\nIn addition first lady Jill Biden and Hunter Biden's wife Melissa, his sister Ashley Biden attended court during the morning session, and his confidant and financier Kevin Morris is also in attendance.\n\nJun 03, 10:26 AM\n\nPresident Biden says he has 'boundless love' for his son\n\nPresident Joe Biden said in a statement issued this morning that he has \"boundless love\" for his son.\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad. Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today. Hunter's resilience in the face of adversity and the strength he has brought to his recovery are inspiring to us,\" Biden said in the statement as jury selection got underway.\n\n\"A lot of families have loved ones who have overcome addiction and know what we mean,\" the president said.\n\n\"As the President, I don't and won't comment on pending federal cases, but as a Dad, I have boundless love for my son, confidence in him, and respect for his strength,\" he said. \"Our family has been through a lot together, and Jill and I are going to continue to be there for Hunter and our family with our love and support.\"\n\nJun 03, 10:10 AM\n\nJurors face individual questioning as Jill Biden looks on\n\nAfter filling out the jury questionnaire, the first panel of prospective jurors are being brought into the court room one-by-one to face individual questioning from the judge and both parties. As of about 9:45 a.m. ET, the court had made it through the questioning of just six jurors.\n\nThe prospective jurors so far have include a woman who worked with the Secret Service for over two decades and whose husband was a uniformed officer in Washington, D.C., at locations including the White House.\n\nOne prospective juror who volunteered for Hilary Clinton's 2008 campaign prompted the first mention of President Joe Biden -- though not by name.\n\nJudge Norieka asked that prospective juror if her work volunteering and donating to Democratic campaigns would prevent her from being fair in a case that involved \"the son of the Democratic president of the United States.\"\n\nShe said it would not.\n\nThe exchange occurred as first lady Jill Biden sat in the front row of the gallery, watching intently as each juror answered their questions. The first lady is sitting next to Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa.\n\nEarlier, a prospective juror was struck for cause because of his firm views on guns, after he told the judge he thought gun ownership was a \"God-given right.\" He said he would not be able to be impartial in a case where someone was prevented from buying a gun due to federal law.\n\nJun 03, 9:39 AM\n\n1st batch of 50 jurors sworn in\n\nHunter Biden's arrival through the front entrance of the J. Caleb Boggs Federal Building this morning means he would have passed an enormous portrait of his father, which hangs in every federal courthouse in the country.\n\nThe first batch of 50 jurors were sworn in by Judge Noreika, who instructed them not to discuss the case with anyone, including family, or to conduct any research on the case or to read any news about it.\n\nReporters monitoring the proceedings from the overflow room could not hear most of Noreika's statement due to technical difficulties. As technicians tried to fix the issue, they turned on a TV that happened to be playing an attack ad against Joe Biden.\n\nJun 03, 8:58 AM\n\nHunter Biden, first lady Jill Biden arrive at courthouse\n\nHunter Biden has arrived at the courthouse for the start of his federal gun trial this morning.\n\nHis mother, first lady Jill Biden, is also attending.\n\nJun 03, 7:46 AM\n\nProspective jurors will be asked about president\n\nTwo hundred and fifty Delaware residents have been summoned to the courthouse in downtown Wilmington, where they will face typical questions about their fitness to serve as jurors.\n\nBut because this is the trial of the son of a sitting president, there will be some novel topics covered during the jury selection process known as \"voir dire.\"\n\nAmong the questions jurors will be asked: \"If you were eligible to vote in any election(s) in which Joseph R. Biden was a candidate, would that fact prevent you from maintaining an open, impartial mind until all of the evidence is presented, and the instructions of the Court are given?\"\n\nAnd \"Do you believe Robert Hunter Biden is being prosecuted in this case because his father is the President of the United States and a candidate for President?\"\n\nJun 03, 7:20 AM\n\nJudge rules annotated form can't be used as evidence\n\nOn the eve of trial, U.S. District Judge Maryellen Noreika threw a wrench in one of the key arguments attorneys for Hunter Biden were planning to advance, ruling that an annotated copy of the federal form Hunter Biden is accused of lying on would be excluded from evidence.\n\nThe original document, called an ATF Form 4473, was created in 2018 when Hunter Biden purchased the firearm. But in 2021, gun store employees made a copy that included some handwritten notes. Defense attorney Abbe Lowell contended that employees had \"tampered with\" the document, and that it raised questions about \"who wrote what on the form, and when.\"\n\nLowell hoped his argument would undermine the credibility of some key government witnesses -- the people who sold Biden the gun -- and potentially create a reasonable doubt that Hunter Biden was the one who actually checked that box.\n\nAttorneys for special counsel David Weiss' office have said the gun shop employees merely \"annotated\" the form and urged Noreika to prevent Lowell from introducing it into evidence.\n\nJury selection is scheduled to get underway today in the federal gun trial of Hunter Biden, who authorities say broke the law when he purchased a Colt revolver in 2018.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's son faces two counts of making false statements while purchasing the firearm and a third count of illegally obtaining it while addicted to drugs.\n\nAlthough the charges together carry a possible sentence of up to 25 years, legal experts say that, as a first-time and nonviolent offender, Hunter Biden would not likely serve time if convicted.\n\nThe trial, in Delaware federal court, is expected to last two to three weeks.", "source": {"uri": "weisradio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WEIS"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashley_Biden", "type": Some questions also examined the prospective jurors' knowledge of the case and view of Hunter Biden.\n\nOn Monday, Hunter Biden arrived at the courthouse in Delaware, and first lady Jill Biden watched from the courtroom's front row. The trial this week makes Hunter Biden the first child of a sitting U.S. president to be criminally tried.\n\nHe previously pleaded not guilty to the charges, saying that he entered a rehab program before purchasing the firearm and checked off \"no\" on a federal form that asked whether he was an \"unlawful user of or addicted to any controlled substance.\"", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", {"uri": "8161363739", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:16:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:16:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:15:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/president-bidens-brother-sons-widow-among-witnesses-expected-at-hunter-bidens-federal-gun-trial/article_d2af6bdc-5cb2-5f0f-9b20-7ed30913f4fd.html", "title": "President Biden's brother, son's widow among witnesses expected at Hunter Biden's federal gun trial", "body": "Hunter Biden, left, arrives with his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden at federal court, Tuesday, June 4, 2024, in Wilmington, Del.\n\nBy CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE - Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as a \"drug addict\" whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018 when he said he wasn't in the throes of addiction.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney said he would call the president's brother James Biden as a witness. James and Hunter are close, and the uncle helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nPeople are also reading... 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Car rolls over on Highway 29 in Napa Napa's Oxbow RiverStage concert series goes on hiatus as promoters seek new site Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda Letter: Concerned for the future of the wine industry NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa doctor launches concierge medical practice and fights obesity epidemic Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing\n\nProsecutors told the jury in their opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer. They also played for jurors an audio excerpt of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things,\" where he talks about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" federal prosecutor Derek Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden, who attended Monday's court session, joined him in the courtroom again as opening statements began.\n\nDefense attorney Abbe Lowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nAnd his state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.''\n\nHe told the jury that prosecutors have to prove that Hunter Biden knowingly violated the law.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the 12-person panel and four alternates.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings are likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was scheduled to travel to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at https://apnews.com/hub/hunter-biden.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161199044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "13:31:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T13:31:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T13:30:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/us/politics/2024/06/04/hunter-biden-gun-trial-latest-live/", "title": "Hunter Biden goes on trial accused of hiding drug addiction to buy a gun - follow live", "body": "Opening arguments will begin today in Hunter Biden's criminal trial for owning a firearm while addicted to illegal drugs.\n\nThe US president's son, 54, is accused of lying about his use of drugs while buying a Colt revolver in Delaware in October 2018. He has pleaded not guilty to the charges.\n\nTwelve jurors selected on Monday will hear evidence including text messages from Mr Biden Jr that refer to him smoking crack cocaine and extracts from his 2021 memoir that discussed his addiction.\n\nMr Biden Jr, a former lawyer, is represented by the veteran political trial attorney Abbe Lowell. The prosecution has been brought by David Weiss, a special counsel appointed by the federal Department of Justice.\n\nThe trial is set to run for around eight days.\n\nFollow below for the latest updates\n\n2:22PM Joe Biden declares 'boundless love' for son Hunter on first day of gun trial\n\nJoe Biden has declared his \"love and support\" for his son Hunter on the first day of his trial for illegal possession of a firearm, as Jill Biden attended the court to watch jury selection.\n\nHunter Biden, 54, is facing federal charges after allegedly lying about his use of illegal drugs at the time he bought a revolver from a Delaware gun store in October 2018.\n\nMrs Biden appeared at the federal district court in Wilmington, Delaware, to witness the beginning of the trial, which took place on her birthday. She is Hunter Biden's stepmother.\n\nYou can read the full report here.\n\n2:15PM Good Afternoon\n\nWelcome to the Telegraph's live coverage of the Hunter Biden trial.\n\nOpening arguments will begin {"uri": "8161267399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "14:13:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T14:13:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T14:13:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/lawyers-begin-opening-statements-in-hunter-bidens-federal-firearms-case/article_d2af6bdc-5cb2-5f0f-9b20-7ed30913f4fd.html", "title": "Lawyers begin opening statements in Hunter Biden's federal firearms case", "body": "Hunter Biden, left, arrives with his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden at federal court, Tuesday, June 4, 2024, in Wilmington, Del.\n\nBy CLAUDIA LAUER, MICHAEL KUNZELMAN, COLLEEN LONG and RANDALL CHASE - Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Lawyers are making opening statements Tuesday in the federal gun case against President Joe Biden's son Hunter in a trial that is expected to feature testimony from his exes and highly personal details about his struggle with addiction.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from a 2018 firearm purchase when he was, according to his memoir, in the throes of a crack addiction. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nHunter Biden arrived at the courthouse with this wife, Melissa, on Tuesday morning, emerging from an SUV. First lady Jill Biden and his sister Ashley Biden joined him again in the courtroom.\n\nPeople are also reading... 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Car rolls over on Highway 29 in Napa Napa's Oxbow RiverStage concert series goes on hiatus as promoters seek new site Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda Letter: Concerned for the future of the wine industry NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa doctor launches concierge medical practice and fights obesity epidemic Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden has pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where, the elder Biden often says, the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily back and forth from Washington, D.C.\n\nPeople just know the story of how Biden's two young sons, Hunter and Beau, were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nSome prospective jurors were dismissed because they knew the family personally, others because they held both positive and negative political views about the Bidens and couldn't be impartial. Still, it took only a day to find the jury of six men and six women plus four women serving as alternates, who will decide the case.\n\nOne potential juror who was sent home said she didn't know whether she could be impartial because of the opinion she had formed about Hunter Biden based on media reports.\n\n\"It's not a good one,\" she said.\n\nAnother was excused because he was aware of the case and said, \"It seems like politics is playing a big role in who gets charged with what and when.\"\n\nBut much of the questioning focused on drug use, addiction and gun ownership, as attorneys sought to test prospective jurors' knowledge of the case, and dismiss those with strong thoughts on drug use, or who might want to regulate firearms -- some of the very people Biden counts as constituents.\n\nThe panel of 12 was chosen out of roughly 65 people. Their names were not made public.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nOpening statements come as Garland faces members of the Republican-led House judiciary committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nThe Delaware trial isn't about Hunter Biden's foreign business affairs, though the proceedings were likely to dredge up dark, embarrassing and painful memories.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's painful past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nIn a statement Monday, the president said he has \"boundless love\" for his son, \"confidence in him and respect for his strength.\"\n\n\"I am the President, but I am also a Dad,\" he said, adding that he would have no further comment on the case. \"Jill and I love our son, and we are so proud of the man he is today.\"\n\nThe first lady sat in court all day Monday, her 73rd birthday, watching the proceedings quietly from the front row behind the defense table, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa, and his sister Ashley. The president was nearby most of the day, camped at their Wilmington home. He departed after court adjourned for a campaign reception in Greenwich, Connecticut.\n\nAboard Air Force One on Monday night, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre was asked if the case might affect the president's ability to do his job, and she replied, \"Absolutely not.\"\n\n\"He always puts the American people first and is capable of doing his job,\" said Jean-Pierre, who declined to say if Biden got updates on the trial throughout the day or spoke to his son after the proceedings concluded.\n\nBiden was traveling to France on Tuesday evening and will be gone the rest of the week. The first lady is scheduled to join him later this week.\n\nThe case against Hunter Biden stems from a period when, by his own public admission, he was addicted to crack. His descent followed the 2015 death of his brother from cancer. He bought and owned a gun for 11 days in October 2018 and indicated on the gun purchase form that he was not using drugs.\n\nIf convicted, Hunter Biden coud face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nTrump is set to be sentenced on July 11 by Judge Juan M. Merchan, who raised the specter of jail time during the trial after the former president racked up thousands of dollars in fines for violating a gag order.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at https://apnews.com/hub/hunter-biden.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8161555357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "17:33:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T17:33:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T17:32:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/prosecutors-play-audio-of-hunter-biden-reading-his-memoir-to-set-scene-at-his-federal/article_d2af6bdc-5cb2-5f0f-9b20-7ed30913f4fd.html", "title": "Prosecutors play audio of Hunter Biden reading his memoir to set scene at his federal gun trial", "body": "Hunter Biden, left, arrives with his wife, Melissa Cohen Biden at federal court, Tuesday, June 4, 2024, in Wilmington, Del.\n\nBy RANDALL CHASE, CLAUDIA LAUER COLLEEN LONG and MICHAEL KUNZELMAN - Associated Press\n\nWILMINGTON, Del. (AP) -- Federal prosecutors on Tuesday painted President Joe Biden's son Hunter as deceptive and driven by addiction, a man whose dark habits ensnared loved ones and who knew what he was doing when he lied on federal forms to purchase a gun in 2018.\n\nMeanwhile, Hunter Biden's attorney argued that his client did not believe he had a drug problem when he stated in the paperwork that he was not in the throes of addiction. Prosecutors, the attorney said, must prove he knowingly violated the law.\n\n\"You will see that he is not guilty,\" attorney Abbe Lowell said in opening statements.\n\nHunter Biden has been charged with three felonies stemming from the purchase of the Colt revolver when he was, according to his memoir, addicted to crack. He has been accused of lying to a federally licensed gun dealer, making a false claim on the application by saying he was not a drug user and illegally having the gun for 11 days.\n\nPeople are also reading... 'The Real Housewives of Napa Valley' debuts Friday Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Napa city Planning Commissioner Bob Massaro dies 'We feel identified': Thousands flock to Napa for La Onda's Latin music showcase Car rolls over on Highway 29 in Napa Napa's Oxbow RiverStage concert series goes on hiatus as promoters seek new site Your guide to Festival La Onda: What to watch for, and how to get around downtown Napa NFL: Former Vintage High lineman and Super Bowl champion Allen dies at age 52 BottleRock organizers tap into the Latino market with Festival La Onda American Canyon High School student arrested after gun found in car Letter: Concerned for the future of the wine industry Festival La Onda takes a bow Sunday, concludes Napa debut Napa doctor launches concierge medical practice and fights obesity epidemic Latin music, Latino fans gained the Napa spotlight at La Onda Napa Police seeks information about motorcyclist reported missing\n\nThe case is dredging up painful memories for the president and his family, and revealing new and highly personal details about their struggles as the 2024 election looms, all while the first lady and Hunter Biden's sister Ashley watch from the front row of the courtroom.\n\nJurors will hear testimony from the president's brother James Biden, who is close with Hunter and helped his nephew through rehab stints in the past. They will also hear how Hallie Biden, the widow of the president's late son, also became addicted to crack during a brief relationship with Hunter. She took the gun from Hunter Biden and tossed it into the garbage at a nearby market, afraid of what he might do with it. The gun was later found by someone collecting cans and eventually turned over to police.\n\nThe president was in Washington as the opening statements were delivered. He announced an immigration order and hosted a picnic for congressional leaders before a scheduled departure for France later in the day. He will be gone the rest of the week. First lady Jill Biden planned to meet him in Europe.\n\nThe president's allies are worried about the toll the trial may take on the elder Biden, who's long been protective and deeply concerned about his only living son and his sobriety and who must now watch as his son's past mistakes are publicly scrutinized. And the president must do so while he's campaigning under anemic poll numbers and preparing for an upcoming presidential debate with Trump.\n\nProsecutors set the stage for their case by playing for jurors audio excerpts of his 2021 memoir \"Beautiful Things\" in which Hunter, in his own narration, talks about about going back to Delaware around the time of the gun purchase and his descent into drugs following the death of his brother, Beau, in 2015 from cancer.\n\nProsecutor Derek Hines told the jury in his opening statement that Hunter Biden was trying to score drugs just days after he lied on the form, telling his brother's widow in a message that he was waiting for a drug dealer.\n\n\"No one is allowed to lie on a federal form like that, even Hunter Biden,\" Hines said. \"He crossed the line when he chose to buy a gun and lied about a federal background check ... the defendant's choice to buy a gun is why we are here.\"\n\n\"When the defendant filled out that form, he knew he was a drug addict,\" and prosecutors don't have to prove he was using that day, Hines said.\n\nHines added: \"Addiction is depressing,\" but Hunter Biden's addiction isn't the reason for the case.\n\nThe proceedings come after the collapse of a deal with prosecutors that would have avoided the spectacle of a trial so close to the 2024 election. Hunter Biden pleaded not guilty and has argued he's being unfairly targeted by the Justice Department after Republicans decried the now-defunct plea deal as special treatment for the Democratic president's son.\n\nLowell said the form asks whether you \"are\" a drug user. \"It does not say 'have you ever been,'\" and he suggested the president's son did not think of himself as someone with a drug problem when he purchased the gun.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHis state of mind should be considered at the time of the purchase, not \"what he wrote in a book in 2021.\"\n\nLowell also blamed Hunter's problems with the firearm on Hallie's disposal of it.\n\n\"After he bought the gun, Hunter did nothing with it,\" Lowell said. The gun became a problem only because of what Hallie Biden did.\n\nLowell cautioned the jury that their duty was solemn and reminded them: \"The charges against Hunter are not minor. They are serious.\"\n\nThe trial is unfolding just days after Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, was convicted of 34 felonies in New York City. The two criminal cases are unrelated, but their proximity underscores how the courts have taken center stage during the 2024 campaign.\n\nJury selection moved at a clip Monday in the president's home state, where Hunter Biden grew up and where the family is deeply established. Joe Biden spent 36 years as a senator in Delaware, commuting daily to Washington.\n\nPeople there are familiar with how Biden's two young sons were injured in the car accident that killed his wife and baby girl in the early 1970s. And Beau Biden was the former state attorney general before he died at age 46 from cancer.\n\nHunter Biden also faces a trial in California in September on charges of failing to pay $1.4 million in taxes. Both cases were to have been resolved through the deal with prosecutors last July, the culmination of a yearslong investigation into his business dealings.\n\nBut Judge Maryellen Noreika, who was nominated to the bench by Trump, questioned some unusual aspects of the deal, which included a proposed guilty plea to misdemeanor offenses to resolve the tax crimes and a diversion agreement on the gun charge, which meant as long as he stayed out of trouble for two years the case would be dismissed.\n\nThe lawyers could not come to a resolution on her questions, and the deal fell apart. Attorney General Merrick Garland then appointed the top investigator, a former U.S. attorney for Delaware, David Weiss, as a special counsel in August, and a month later Hunter Biden was indicted.\n\nGarland on Tuesday faced members of the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee in Washington, which has been investigating the president and his family and whose chairman has been at the forefront of a stalled impeachment inquiry stemming from Hunter Biden's business dealings.\n\nIf convicted, he could face up to 25 years in prison, though first-time offenders do not get anywhere near the maximum, and it's unclear whether the judge would give him time behind bars.\n\nLong reported from Washington. Associated Press writers Alanna Durkin Richer in Washington and Fatima Hussein aboard Air Force One contributed to this report.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of Hunter Biden at https://apnews.com/hub/hunter-biden.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. The box where he allegedly checked \"no\" asked the gun buyer: \"Are you an unlawful user of, or addicted to\" various narcotics.\n\n\"The issue here is Mr. Biden's understanding of the question, which asks in the present tense if he 'is' a user or addict,\" Lowell wrote in court papers.\n\n\"The terms 'user' or 'addict' are not defined on the form and were not explained to him,\" Lowell wrote. \"Someone like Mr. Biden who had just completed an 11-day rehabilitation program and lived with a sober companion after that, could surely believe he was not a present tense user or addict.\"\n\nAfter the parties deliver opening statements, prosecutors expect to call as their first witness FBI Special Agent Erika Jensen, who is expected to introduce into evidence several of Hunter Biden's text messages and excerpts from his 2021 memoir, \"Beautiful Things,\" as well other evidence.\n\nFirst lady Jill Biden attended Day 1 of the trial Monday, as did Hunter Biden's wife, Melissa Cohen, and his stepsister, Ashley Biden. President Joe Biden spent the day nearby at his and the first lady's Wilmington home.\n\nBefore the trial began, the parties projected it could take up to three days to select a jury, but they completed the task in only one day -- meaning proceedings are thus far running ahead of schedule.\n\nJudge Maryellen Noreika told jurors they would likely need to be available for the trial through June 14, with the possibility of deliberations stretching into the week of June 17.", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
